citation.article-title: Janibacter brevis sp. nov., a new trichloroethylene-degrading bacterium isolated from polluted environments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Janibacter brevis sp. nov.
Janibacter brevis (bre'vis. L. adj. brevis short)
Colonies are white, opaque and convex with a glistening surface and entire margins on good growth media.
Cells are Gram-positive and non-motile, occur singly, in pairs or occasionally in v-shaped clumps at the early stage of growth.
Cells are short rods in young culture, 0.9-1.0 μm in diameter and 1.5-1.8 μm long, and coccoid cells in the stationary phase of growth, 1.0-1.2 μmin diameter and 1.2-1.3 μm long.
A marked rod-coccus cycle is not observed.
The optimal growth temperature is 25-28 °C.
Obligately aerobic.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Oxidase-negative.
Catalase-positive.
H2S and indole are not produced.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Thiamine is required for growth.
Formation of acids from sugars and alcohols is not observed.

Cells utilize D-fructose, D-glucose, lactose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose, inositol, acetate, butyrate, citrate, gluconate, hippurate, DL-lactate, pyruvate, valeric acid and various amino acids as sole carbon sources.

L-Arabinose, D-xylose, D-mannose, L-sorbose, D-cellobiose, galactose, mannitol, D-sorbitol, methanol, ethanol, propanol, cis-aconitate, trans-aconitate, benzoate, formate, malate, malonate, succinate and L-tartarate are not utilized.
meso-Diaminopimelic acid is contained in peptidoglycan.
The acyl type is acetyl.
In whole-cell hydrolysates, ribose and glucose are present, but arabinose, galactose and mannose are absent.
The major menaquinone is MK-8(H4).
The major fatty acids are i-C15:0, i-C16:0, i-C17:0, i-C17:1 and ai-C17:0 as the branched acids and C18:1Δ11 as the straight chain acid.
The polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
Mycolic acids are absent.
The DNA base composition is 72 mol% G+­C.
The type strain is strain 10NT.
Strains 10NT and 16N have been deposited in the IAM (Institute of Cellular and Molecular Sciences, University of Tokyo) Culture Collection as IAM 14781T and IAM 14782, respectively.
